unnormalised: **Telecommunications: Fiber-to-Home Expansion Gains Momentum in India**
normalised: **Telecommunications: Fiber-to-Home Expansion Gains Momentum in India**

unnormalised: New Delhi, October 26 - The rollout of Fiber-to-Home (FTTH) infrastructure across India is gaining significant momentum, spearheaded by both public and private sector telecommunications companies. Bharat Sanchar Nigam Limited (BSNL) is reportedly accelerating its FTTH deployment in rural areas, aiming to connect over 50,000 villages by the end of FY24.
normalised: New Delhi, october twenty sixth - The rollout of Fiber-to-Home (F T T H) infrastructure across India is gaining significant momentum, spearheaded by both public and private sector telecommunications companies. Bharat Sanchar Nigam Limited (B S N L) is reportedly accelerating its F T T H deployment in rural areas, aiming to connect over fifty thousand villages by the end of F Y twenty four.

unnormalised: Reliance Jio continues its aggressive expansion in urban centers, claiming to have connected over 8 million homes already. Dr. Rajesh Kumar, a telecom analyst, notes that this surge is driven by increasing demand for high-speed internet for remote work, online education, and streaming entertainment.
normalised: Reliance Jio continues its aggressive expansion in urban centers, claiming to have connected over eight million homes already. Doctor Rajesh Kumar, a telecom analyst, notes that this surge is driven by increasing demand for high-speed internet for remote work, online education, and streaming entertainment.

unnormalised: The Indian government is providing incentives, including reduced right-of-way charges, to encourage faster deployment. Investment in FTTH is expected to reach Rs. 20,000 Crores this fiscal year alone. Analysts predict FTTH coverage will surpass 60% of Indian households within the next three years. This expansion will also fuel growth in related sectors such as smart home devices and cloud computing, impacting properties ranging from modest 500 sq ft apartments to sprawling bungalows.
normalised: The Indian government is providing incentives, including reduced right-of-way charges, to encourage faster deployment. Investment in F T T H is expected to reach rupees twenty thousand crores this fiscal year alone. Analysts predict F T T H coverage will surpass sixty percent of Indian households within the next three years. This expansion will also fuel growth in related sectors such as smart home devices and cloud computing, impacting properties ranging from modest five hundred square feet apartments to sprawling bungalows.
